entry.title: Pashinyan makes return visit to Tavush border villages

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan makes return visit to Tavush border villages
media:group.media:description:
üìç Russian peacekeepers have begun withdrawing from Nagorno-Karabakh over a year ahead of schedule. üìç Prime Minister Pashinyan makes a second visit to Tavush border villages as Azerbaijan demands handover of adjoining territory. üìç Iran says Armenia has given it assurances that ties with the West are not aimed against it. üìç It is alleged an Armenian citizen was beaten by a group of masked persons after insulting a ruling party lawmaker. üìç Watch More: John Hodian of the Naghash Ensemble- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YB5oA5yS5A0
Credits: Ruptly

entry.title: ‚ÄúArmenia Could Become a World Engineering Hub‚Äù

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄúArmenia Could Become a World Engineering Hub‚Äù
media:group.media:description:
Vahe Nigoghosian is the founder of Engineer X, a multi-disciplinary engineering firm based in Armenia that focuses on business and education. Vahe brought with him the branch of the Dassault Systemes, a French multinational software corporation which develops software for 3D product design, simulation, manufacturing and other 3D related products. Vahe Nigoghosian has two hopes. First, to see Armenia become a world Engineering Hub. Andsecond, see more young Armenians embrace engineering.

entry.title: Caviar Diplomacy and the Middle Corridor: How does Azerbaijan avoid sanctions?

media:group.media:title: Caviar Diplomacy and the Middle Corridor: How does Azerbaijan avoid sanctions?
media:group.media:description:
Rasmus Canb√§ck, an investigative journalist for the Swedish online news site Blankspot, talks to CivilNet‚Äôs Paul Vartan Sookiasian about how Azerbaijan manages to avoid international sanctions despite ethnically cleansing Armenians from Nagorno-Karabakh. While fossil fuels and ‚Äúcaviar diplomacy‚Äù play a role, Canb√§ck says more attention should be paid to Azerbaijan‚Äôs geographic position on the ‚Äúmiddle corridor‚Äù between Europe and China.
0:00 Where are the red lines for the European Union to sanction Azerbaijan? 3:36 The Middle Corridor as a reason for lack of accountability on Azerbaijan. 5:43 'Caviar diplomacy' and the response to the ethnic cleansing of Nagorno-Karabakh. 10:20 A clash between realpolitik and humanitarian policy or hypocrisy? 12:45 Using social media to spark debate.

entry.title: ‚ÄúDiscovering Armenia felt like I finally came home, at my source‚Äù, John Hodian

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄúDiscovering Armenia felt like I finally came home, at my source‚Äù, John Hodian
media:group.media:description:
00:00 ‚Äì intro 1:00 Childhood and family context 3:46 Historical roots & the Armenian genocide 5:59 Generational trauma 7:33 Entry in music 9:33 Career and scoring films 11:49 Discovering Armenia 16:30 Mkrtich Naghash and the birth of the Ensemble 26:10 Tigran Mansuryan 33:12 Inspiring in times of chaos
In this episode of Mindful Leaders, we explore the life of John Hodian, composer, conductor, pianist and founder of The Naghash Ensemble. Born and raised in Philadelphia to Armenian parents, John‚Äôs grandparents were survivors of the Armenian genocide, notably from the village of Perchendz near Kharpert. Around the age of 12, John serendipitously discovered the piano, which opened the gateways to his career in music as a composer and conductor. He has written scores for numerous feature films, dance pieces, musicals and over 300 documentaries, earning international recognition and awards, including an Emmy. Soon after his first visit to Armenia, he discovered the poetry of a 15th-century Armenian priest exiled from Dyarbekir named Der Mkrtich Naghash. This inspired John to compose a cycle of new music, and to establish the famous Naghash ensemble. In this segment, we explore John's journey since leaving Philadelphia, his ancestral roots, the blessings that led him to discover Armenia, and the magic of the Naghash Ensemble, which continues to extend a piece of Armenia to the world.
About John Hodian
John Hodian is a composer, conductor, pianist and founder of the Naghash Ensemble. Following his studies in composition and conducting at The Philadelphia College for the Performing Arts, he embarked on a journey of teaching composition and music theory at the University of the Arts. He became the conductor of the Philadelphia New Music Ensemble and associate conductor of The Philadelphia Youth Orchestra, after which he moved to New York and developed his career in film and television scoring. John‚Äôs music has been heard in Emmy award-winning soundtracks for feature films and documentaries, commissioned scores for dance companies, as well as stage dramas and musicals. He has scored over 300 documentary films and won the New York Emmy Award for "Best Music for a Documentary." In 2010, John founded the Naghash Ensemble and composed its music based on sacred texts by the medieval Armenian poet and priest Mkrtich Naghash. The Ensemble has been touring regularly in Europe and in North America.
Program Overview Mindful Leaders dives into the stories of people who have achieved prominence, walked incredible journeys, and have defined culture.
Lara sits down with specialists, thinkers, and change catalysts to deconstruct insights, events, and lessons that have shaped their personal and professional lives and have enabled them to create meaning and connection.
#MindfulLeaders #InheritedLegacies #CivilNet
